entry.title: Re: A fee-bumping model
entry.summary:
The discussion revolves around various models for rewarding Lightning Network (LN) watchtowers, including per-penalty on-chain bounties, per-job micropayments, and customer subscriptions. For further details, the work-in-progress specification can be accessed at [this link](https://github.com/sr-gi/bolt13/blob/master/13-watchtowers.md). Additionally, there is a consideration for Lightning Service Providers (LSPs) to use batch closure of channels, utilizing CPFP (Child Pays for Parent) to manage multiple commitment transactions and employing RBF (Replace-By-Fee) when necessary. A concern is raised about potential malicious actions by counterparties, such as forcing unilateral channel closures to uncover the full-node topologies of watchtowers through fee-bumping transaction observations. It is suggested that an ordering algorithm might help in deciding which tower performs fee-bumping first to prevent this.
The email also touches upon the potential deprecation of CPFP carve-out following the deployment of package relay and RBF mechanisms hardened against pinning. This would counteract abuse by ensuring that RBF'd packages evict malicious transactions, starting with the root commitment transaction. Moreover, it hints at the applicability of these strategies to n-party contracts that include "any-contract-can-spend" anchor outputs.
The importance of a strategic approach to fee-bumping is emphasized, particularly in response to rapid changes in HTLC traffic within the global network, suggesting that LSPs may need to accelerate fee-bumping to reallocate liquidity efficiently. The conversation also delves into the economics of fee-bumping, highlighting the risk of miners manipulating fee rates by exploiting desperate fee-bumping, thus underscoring the need for caution in adopting increasingly aggressive fee-bumping strategies.
Further insights are offered on fee management, stating that, in certain cases, preserving fee reserves might be preferable to continual fee bumping, given that the transaction weight does not always correlate with the value at stake. A recommendation for exploring DLC (Discreet Log Contracts) spec fee-bumping guidelines is provided for additional context, available at [this link](https://github.com/discreetlogcontracts/dlcspecs/blob/master/Non-Interactive-Protocol.md).
Lastly, the email points out the difficulty in devising effective fee-bumping strategies due to the unpredictable nature of miner behavior and the broader implications for network dynamics. It concludes with a note on the potential research value in understanding and mitigating such challenges, directing to further analysis at [Linux Foundation's mailing list archive](https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/lightning-dev/2020-February/002569.html).
